introduction.p: In this chapter we will focus on common accompanimental textures. This chapter does not make an attempt to catalog every known accompanimental texture. Instead, it is meant to encourage you to listen to texture more closely and increase your musical awareness.

section.title: Texture
section.p: We will consider texturetexture in terms of vertical and horizontal elements. The vertical nature of texture relates to the number of notes occurring simultaneously as harmonies. It could also relate to the number of voices or instruments performing melodies simultaneously in a contrapuntal texture. The horizontal element of texture relates to rhythmic activity: is the most common rhythmic value in a passage a slow or fast one?
To illustrate, here is a texture with chords (vertical elements) containing five voices with a melody (a sixth voice) above. Notice that the texture has slow rhythmic values on the horizontal plane.

figure.caption: Barber, Adagio for Strings

section.p: Our second example is an excerpt for four instrumentsa string quartet. While this a four-voice texture, it is full of rhythmic activity. The most common rhythmic value is the sixteenth note, and the syncopated figures in measures 34 of the Violin I part and measures 56 of the Viola part add to the textural complexity.

figure.caption: Mozart, String Quartet K. 428, IV

section.p: In the following sections, we will examine fairly straightforward melody-and-accompaniment textures in classical and popular music. In later chapters we will explore more complex textures.

section.title: Chorale Texture
section.p: Chorale textures are those in which there is a chord for every (or nearly every) melody note. A familiar example of chorale texture is the StarSpangled Banner.

figure.caption: Francis Scott Key and John Stafford Smith, The Star-Spangled Banner

section.p: In the following example by Schubert, the melody at times moves in a slightly different rhythm that the chords below.

figure.caption: Schubert, Winterreise, D.911, Die Nebensonnen

section.p: Chorale textures are also described as homorhythmic because all of the parts move in the same rhythm.

figure.caption: Bhasker, Ruess, Dost, Antonoff, Some Nights

section.p: In the next section we will examine arpeggiated accompaniments.

subsection.title: Arpeggios
subsection.p: One way to express chords rhythmically is through arpeggios in one part and a bass line in octaves in a lower part, as in the following example from Beethovenâ€™s Moonlight Sonata.

figure.caption: Beethoven, Moonlight Sonata, Op. 27, No. 2, I

subsection.p: The next example has descending arpeggios.

figure.caption: Keys, If I Ain't Got You

idx.h: If I Ain't Got You (Alicia Keys)

subsection.p: Notice that in both the Beethoven and Alicia Keys examples there is the harmonious interval of a tenth (an octave plus a third) between the bass (lowest) voice and the soprano (highest) voice.
The following examples have arpeggios that ascend and descend through a chord.

figure.caption: Pankow, Colour My World
Ball, Angel, and Fenty, Love on the Brain

subsection.p: Notice in the above example that there is also an organ playing block chords to create a sense of legato in the texture.
The next two examples are from more recent popular music.

figure.caption: Adkins and Wilson, Someone Like You
Tedder, Secrets

subsection.p: Below is an example in with arpeggios in sixteenth notes.

figure.caption: Briggs, Burress, Cottle, Lopes, No Scrubs

subsection.title: Alberti Bass
subsection.p: Alberti bass accompaniment patterns involve arpeggios that do not arpeggiate chords in a simple upward or downward motion, but in a lowhighmiddlehigh pattern as you can see in the examples below.

figure.caption: Mozart, Piano Sonata K. 545, I

subsection.p: The next example uses the same Alberti pattern as in the Mozart example above, but transposed to E minor and in a lower register.

figure.caption: Carman and Spickard, Pipeline

introduction.p: This section contains the following subsections below:

subsection.title: The 1 (2) Rhythm
subsection.p: In this section, we will discuss some accompanimental rhythms that occur frequently in popular music. The first such rhythm has two chords per measure, with the first chord on beat 1 and the second chord on the upbeat after beat 2.

figure.caption: Gaye and Townsend, Let's Get It On

subsection.p: You will find a similar rhythm and bass line in the next example.

figure.caption: Sheeran, Thinking Out Loud

subsection.p: The 1 (2) rhythm is also found in Donâ€™t You (Forget About Me), a song associated with the film The Breakfast Club.

figure.caption: Forsey and Schiff, Donâ€™t You (Forget About Me)

subsection.p: Below are five more examples of block chord accompaniment in the 1 (2) rhythm.

figure.caption: A. Wilson, N. Wilson, Ennis, Knight, and Block, Never
Sebert, Gottwald, Blanco, Tik Tok
Mars, Lawrence, Brown, Fauntlery, Yip, Romulus, Reeves, McCullough II, That's What I Like
Franks, Puth, Thomaz, See You Again

idx.h: See You Again (Wiz Khalifa ft. Charlie Puth)

figure.caption: Arthur, Ormandy, Solomon, Say You Won't Let Go

idx.h: Say You Won't Let Go (James Arthur)

subsection.p: The example below has the 1 (2) rhythm in dimininution.

figure.caption: Bieber, Blanco, and Sheeran, Love Yourself

subsection.title: The Barbara Ann Rhythm
subsection.p: It is easier to describe the next block chord accompaniment pattern as the Barbara Ann rhytm than the 1 2 3 (4) (1) (2) 3 rhythm. Below are six examples of pieces that use this rhythm, whether with block chords or solely in the bass line.

figure.caption: Fassert, Barbara Ann
HollandDozierHolland, You Can't Hurry Love
Allen, Hall, and Oates, Maneater
Rew, Walking On Sunshine

idx.h: Walking On Sunshine (Katrina and the Waves)

figure.caption: Ceste and Muncey, Are You Gonna Be My Girl

idx.h: Are You Gonna Be My Girl (Jet)

subsection.p: A slower version of this rhythm occurs in Deep Purpleâ€™s Smoke on the Water.

figure.caption: Blackmore, Gillan, Glover, Lord, and Paice, Smoke on the Water

subsection.title: Repeated 8thnote Chords
subsection.p: Repeated 8thnote chords occur regularly in Classical music textures.

figure.caption: Mozart, Piano Sonata K. 310, I
Schubert, Winterreise, D. 911Gute Nacht
Robert Schumann, Dichterliebe, Ich grolle nicht

subsection.p: The next example is from the musical Annie. Note the 1 (2) rhythm in the bass line.

figure.caption: Strouse and Charnin, Annie, It's the Hard Knock Life

idx.h: It's the Hard Knock Life (from Annie)

subsection.p: Repeated eighth notes are a standard accompanimental texture in rock.

figure.caption: Gill and Wade, Heartbreaker

subsection.p: The repeated eighthnote rhythm is also common in recent popular music. Note that the following example uses the 1950's progression (i.e., ).

figure.caption: Ruess, Dost, Antonoff, and Bhasker, We Are Young

subsection.title: Repeated Quarternote Chords
subsection.p: Repeated quarternote chords are a common accompanimental rhythm in Classical and popular music.

figure.caption: Handel, Xerxes, Ombra mai fu
Joel, She's Got a Way
Gramm and Jones, Cold As Ice
Sumner, Roxanne
Bublé, Chang, and Foster-Gilles, Havenâ€™t Met You Yet
Bareilles, Love Song

subsection.p: In the next section, we will examine accompanimental textures consisting of afterbeats and offbeats.

subsection.title: Afterbeats
subsection.p: The term afterbeats is from Fundamentals of Musical Composition by noted composer and pedagogue Arnold Schoenberg. Afterbeatsafterbeats are repeated chords (usually eighth notes, sometimes quarter notes) that occur after the downbeat.

figure.caption: Beethoven, Piano Sonata Op. 2, No. 1, IV

subsection.p: In the next example, the afterbeats are not repeated chords but instead are passingtone figures harmonized in thirds.

figure.caption: Mozart, Piano Sonata K. 279, III

introduction.p: Offbeatsoffbeats are typically chords that occur regularly on upbeats, avoiding downbeats. While there are many styles of music that use chordal offbeats, in this section we will consider only polka and reggae styles.

subsubsection.title: Polka
subsubsection.p: The polka, which originated in Bohemia, has connotations with Germary and Oktoberfest. The polka in the United States is often associated with Frankie Yankovic, who was known as the Polka King.

figure.caption: Vejvoda, Beer Barrel Polka

subsubsection.title: Reggae
subsubsection.p: Reggae is associated with the island of Jamaica and, in the most elemental sense, is characterized by offbeats, often played on an electric guitar. Bob Marley is closely associated with reggae music.

figure.caption: Marley, Could You Be Loved

subsubsection.p: By the late 1970s, British bands like The Police and UB40 were recording songs that used the reggae accompanimental style.

figure.caption: Sumner, Walking on the Moon (1979)
Diamond, Red Red Wine (recorded in 1983 by UB40)

subsubsection.p: Reggae accompanimental texture is fairly common in the present day, as can be heard in the following examples.

figure.caption: Stefani and Stewart, Underneath It All (2001)
Mraz, I'm Yours (2007)
Atwey, Messinger, Pellizzer, Spivak, Tanas, Rude (2013)

introduction.p: The 32 clavé (and the 23 clavé) 32 claveare essential rhythmic elements in Afro-Cuban music. In this section we will see how cross rhythms implied by the 32 clavé can be viewed as a possible source of cross rhythms in popular music. Here is a video demonstration of a 32 clavé.
Here is rhythmic notation of a 32 clavé. Notice there are three attacks in the first measure and 2 attacks in the second bar.
The rhythm underlying the first bar is 3+3+2.
The 32 Clavé has also been called the Bo Diddley BeatBo Diddley beat because of its use by Bo Diddley in the 1950s. Look at the rhythms shown above as you listen to the following examples.

figure.caption: Dixon, Pretty Thing
Berns, Feldman, Goldstein, and Gottehrer, I Want Candy
Ballard, Back in the New York Groove

idx.h: Back in the New York Groove (Ace Frehley)

figure.caption: Michael, Faith
U2, Desire

introduction.p: In the examples below, only the first bar of the 32 clavé is used. Below, the 3+3+2 rhythm is shown in both eighth notes and sixteenth notes.
The example below shows the sixteenthnote subdivisions in the 3+3+2 rhythm.
Below are different ways of notating the sixteenthnote version 3+3+2 rhythm.
The first example, by the Rebirth Brass Band, uses a second line drumming pattern, which is associated with second line parades in New Orleans.

figure.caption: Calloway, Casanova

introduction.p: The wellknown introduction to Eye of the Tiger uses the 3+3+2 rhythm.

figure.caption: Sullivan and Peterik, Eye of the Tiger

introduction.p: In the following example from Cyndi Lauper's Girls Just Want to Have Fun, the lead electric guitar riff emphasizes a 3+3+2 rhythm in 16th notes on each downbeat.

figure.caption: Chertoff and Wittman, Girls Just Want to Have Fun

idx.h: Girls Just Want to Have Fun (Cyndi Lauper)

introduction.p: Below is an example showing the 3+3+2 rhythm (in 16th notes) immediately repeated. The rhythm is shown in two possible notations below.
The following three examples all use the (3+3+2)+(3+3+2) rhythm as a rhythmic ostinato or groove.

figure.caption: Legend and Gad, All of Me
Mendes, Geiger, and Harris, Treat You Better
Sheeran, Mac, McDaid, Burruss, Cottle, and Briggs, Shape of You

introduction.p: This rhythm also occurs in the following classical piece by Ligeti.

figure.caption: Ligeti, Trio for Violin, Horn, and Piano, II

idx.h: Trio for Violin, Horn, and Piano, II

introduction.p: The following examples have the (3+3+2)+(3+3+2) rhythm in 8th notes.

figure.caption: Berryman, Buckland, Champion, and Martin, Clocks
Grohl, Hawkins, Mendel, Shiflett, Best of You
Atwey, Messinger, Pellizzer, Spivak, Tanas, Rude

subsubsection.title: Habanera and Reggaeton
subsubsection.p: The reggaeton beat is built from a 3+3+2 rhythm. We will see a relationship between the reggaeton beat with the habanera. First, let us examine the famous Habanera bass line from the opera Carmen.

figure.caption: Bizet, Carmen, Habanera (L'amour est un oiseau rebelle)

idx.h: Carmen, Habanera (L'amour est un oiseau rebelle)

subsubsection.p: Compare the habanera pattern above to the reggaeton beat below, notated for bass drum and snare drum.
Compare the reggaeton rhythm to the 3+3+2 of the first bar of a 32 clavé (refer to the second measure in the example below).
Here are examples of songs with a reggaeton beat.

figure.caption: Johnson and Browne, Dem Bow
Graham, Jefferies, Shebib, Balogun, Reid, Smith, One Dance
Rodriguez, Ender, and Ayala, Despacito
Bieber, Michaels, Tranter, Moore, and Tucker, Sorry
Ørsted, Parmenius, and Emenike, Final Song
Levine, Ryan, Hindlin, Tranter, and Shaouy, Cold

subsubsection.p: In the next two sections, we will examine expansions of the 3+3+2 rhythm

subsection.p: In this section, we will see each number in the 3+3+2 pattern repeated, generating the 3+3+3+3+2+2 pattern.
Listen for the 3+3+3+3+2+2 in the following examples.

figure.caption: U2, Beautiful Day
Frances and Reid, You Know You Like It

idx.h: You Know You Like It (Aluna George, DJ Snake Remix)

figure.caption: Bennett, Glynne, Patterson, and Wroldsen, Hold My Hand

subsection.title: 8 Groups of 3 Plus 4 Groups of 2
subsection.p: the 3+3+2 pattern can also be expanded to 8 groups of 3 sixteenth notes followed by 4 groups of 2 sixteenth notes, as shown in the example below.
Listen for this rhythm in the examples below.

figure.caption: Parker, Jr., Ghostbusters
Pink, Martin, Schuster, Raise Your Glass
Too Many Zooz, Warriors

subsubsection.title: Other Combinations of 3s and 2s
subsubsection.p: You will also find other combinations of 3s and 2s (or 3s and 4s).

figure.caption: Stefan Gordy and Skyler Gordy, Party Rock Anthem

subsubsection.p: The rhythm in the above example is dissected below.
Listen for the 3+3+4+3+3 rhythm in the following examples.

figure.caption: Maraj, Khayat, Falk, Yacoub, Hector, and Hajji, Starships
Martin, Kotecha, Salmanzadeh, Kelly, Grande, Problem

subsubsection.p: One also finds the 3+3+4+3+3 pattern in the second bar of Tik Tok, an example from earlier in the chapter.

figure.caption: Sebert, Gottwald, Blanco, Tik Tok

introduction.p: Sometimes the identity of a song is in its repeated bass line (known as a riff, which is a short repeated pattern). Listen to the distinctive bass lines in the following examples.

figure.caption: Winner, Little Brown Jug (1939)
LennonMcCartney, Day Tripper (1965)
The Sugarhill Gang, O'Brien, Robinson, Rodgers, Edwards, and Grandmaster Caz, Rapper's Delight (1979)
Deacon, Another One Bites the Dust (1980)
James, Superfreak (1981)
Bowie, Under Pressure (1981)
Kelly, Aitchison, Astasio, Pebworth, Shave, McKenzie, Fancy (2014)
Haggerty, Lewis, Dutton, Nally, Karp, Rawlings, Asplund, FloryBarnes, Haggerty, Downtown (2015)

subsection.title: Distinctive Guitar Riffs
subsection.p: You will also find distinctive riffs played by guitar in conjunction with bass, as in the following examples.

figure.caption: Davies, You Really Got Me (1964)
Page and Plant, Immigrant Song (1970)
Tyler and Perry, Walk This Way (1975)
A. Young, M. Young, and Johnson, Back in Black (1980)

subsection.p: This chapter is meant to give you ideas about animating chords and chord progressions with accompanimental textures, including riffs. It is by no means meant to be exhaustive, but rather to encourage you to listen closely to texture and accompaniment.
